{{Coord|26|26|44.4|N|87|16|25.7|E|type:edu|display=title}} {{Use British English|date=October 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox university |name = Mahendra Morang Adarsh Multiple Campus |native_name = महेन्द्र मोरङ आदर्श बहुमुखी क्याम्पस |native_name_lang = ne |established = 1955 (2012 B.S.)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mmamc.edu.np/index.php/about-us|title=History of Mahendra Morang Adarsh Multiple Campus|accessdate=19 October 2018}}</ref> |type = [[Public]] |affiliation = [[Tribhuvan University]] |address = [[Biratnagar]], [[Morang]] |country =[[Nepal]] |principal = Babu Ram Timalsina<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mmamc.edu.np/index.php/about-us|title=History of Mahendra Morang Adarsh Multiple Campus|accessdate=19 October 2018}}</ref> |academic_staff= 165<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mmamc.edu.np/index.php/about-us|title=History of Mahendra Morang Adarsh Multiple Campus|accessdate=19 October 2018}}</ref> |other_name = MMAMC |students = 3234<ref>{{cite web|url=https://udghoshdaily.com/%E0%A4%B5%E0%A4%BF%E0%A4%9A%E0%A4%BE%E0%A4%B0/2378-2018-07-24-12-30-15|title=महेन्द्र मोरङ क्याम्पस: प्राज्ञिक उत्कृष्टता केन्द्रको सम्भावना|accessdate=19 October 2018}}</ref> |language = [[Nepali language|Nepali]], [[English language|English]] |website = http://www.mmamc.edu.np }}
'''Mahendra Morang Adarsh Multiple Campus''' ({{lang-ne|[[:ne:महेन्द्र मोरङ आदर्श बहुमुखी क्याम्पस ]]}}) is a constituent campus of [[Tribhuvan University]] in [[Biratnagar]], [[Morang]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Homepage of Mahendra Morang Adarsh Multiple Campus|url=http://www.mmamc.edu.np/|publisher=Mahendra Morang Adarsh Multiple Campus|accessdate=19 October 2018}}</ref><ref name="TU">{{cite web|title=List of Constituent Campuses|url=http://tribhuvan-university.edu.np/academics/campuses/|publisher=Tribhuvan University|accessdate=19 October 2018}}</ref> Established in 1955, with the name Morang Intermediate College, is one of the oldest constituent campuses of Tribhuvan University in the district.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mmamc.edu.np/index.php/about-us|title=History of Mahendra Morang Adarsh Multiple Campus|accessdate=19 October 2018}}</ref> There are 165 academic staffs<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mmamc.edu.np/index.php/about-us|title=History of Mahendra Morang Adarsh Multiple Campus|accessdate=19 October 2018}}</ref> and 3234 students<ref>{{cite web|url=https://udghoshdaily.com/%E0%A4%B5%E0%A4%BF%E0%A4%9A%E0%A4%BE%E0%A4%B0/2378-2018-07-24-12-30-15|title=महेन्द्र मोरङ क्याम्पस: प्राज्ञिक उत्कृष्टता केन्द्रको सम्भावना|accessdate=19 October 2018}}</ref> studying in the college.On 15 April 2018, Tribhuvan University elected the college administration to be headed by Babu Ram Timalsina, who is often referred to as "Campus Chief".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ehimalayatimes.com/interview/25409/|title=मोरङ क्याम्पस विश्वविद्यालय बन्नुपर्छ|date=16 July 2018|language=Nepali|accessdate=19 October 2018}}</ref>
==History== Mahendra Morang Adarsha Multiple Campus is the constituent campus of [[Tribhuvan University]] in [[Province No. 1]]. It was established in 2012 B.S. With the name of Morang Intermediate College and it has come a long history since then. In the very first year of its establishment, it was able to make a record of hundred percent result in the faculty of humanities.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mmamc.edu.np/index.php/about-us|title=History of Mahendra Morang Adarsh Multiple Campus|accessdate=19 October 2018}}</ref> Established before [[Tribhuvan University]], Mahendra Morang Adarsh Multiple Campus has a notable history for serving the education in Nepal. The campus building completed its construction in 2018 B.S. After the inaguration of the building in 2020 B.S. by [[Mahendra of Nepal]], the word "Mahendra" was added to the name of the campus in 2020 B.S. being Mahendra Morang College. With the implementation of new education system in 2028 B.S. [[Tribhuvan University]] converted into its constituent campus. After the merging of Adarsh Mahabidhyalaya, it was ultimately named as Mahendra Morang Adarsh Multiple Campus.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://udghoshdaily.com/%E0%A4%B5%E0%A4%BF%E0%A4%9A%E0%A4%BE%E0%A4%B0/2378-2018-07-24-12-30-15|title=महेन्द्र मोरङ क्याम्पस: प्राज्ञिक उत्कृष्टता केन्द्रको सम्भावना|accessdate=19 October 2018}}</ref>
==Academics== The campus offers following bachelor's and master's degree courses:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mmamc.edu.np/index.php/program|title=Programs|accessdate=19 October 2018}}</ref> *[[Bachelor's degree]] **[[Bachelor of Science]] **[[Bachelor of Arts]] **Bachelor of Business Studies **[[Bachelor of Education]] **[[Bachelor of Business Administration]] **[[Bachelor of Public Administration]] **B.Sc Microbiology
*[[Master's degree]] *M.Sc in Physics *M. Sc. in Chemistry *M. Sc. in Microbiology *[[Master of Public Administration]] *MBS *M.A. in English *[[Master of Education]] ==Notable alumni==
Some of the eminent graduates of the college include: #[[President of Nepal]], [[Bidhya Devi Bhandari]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://therisingnepal.org.np/news/12972|title=Global Influence Of Women In Politics|accessdate=19 October 2018}}</ref> #Former Chief Justice of [[Supreme Court of Nepal]], [[Sushila Karki]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.inheadline.com/news/biography-of-bidhya-devi-bhandari-first-female-president-of-nepal|title=Biography of Bidhya Devi Bhandari: First Female President of Nepal|accessdate=19 October 2018}}</ref>
==See also== * [[List of universities and colleges in Nepal]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Universities and colleges in Nepal]] [[Category:Education in Nepal]]

{{Infobox government agency |agency_name = Ministry of Education and Sports |type = Ministry |nativename = |nativename_a = |nativename_r = |logo = |logo_width = 150 px |logo_caption = |seal = File:Coat of arms of Uganda.svg |seal_width = 150px |seal_caption = Coat of Arms of Uganda |picture = |picture_width = |picture_caption = |formed = |preceding1 = |preceding2 = |dissolved = |superseding = |jurisdiction = [[Government of Uganda]] |headquarters =[[Kampala]], [[Uganda]] |region_code = |coordinates = |motto = |employees = |budget = |minister1_name = |minister1_pfo = |minister2_name = |minister2_pfo = |deputyminister1_name = |deputyminister1_pfo = |deputyminister2_name = |deputyminister2_pfo = |chief1_name = [[Janet Museveni]] |chief1_position =
Minister of Education and Sports |chief2_name = |chief2_position = |agency_type = Ministry |parent_department = |parent_agency = |keydocument1 = |website = {{URL|http://www.education.go.ug/}} |footnotes = |map = |map_width = |map_caption = }} The '''Ministry of Education and Sports''' (MES), is a [[Cabinet of Uganda|cabinet-level ministry of Uganda]]. It is mandated "to provide technical support, guide, coordinate, regulate and promote quality education, training and sports to all persons in Uganda for national integration, development and individual advancement", according to the website of the ministry.{{cite web| location=Kampala| author=MES |date=15 October 2016 |url=http://www.education.go.ug/data/smenu/47/About%20the%20Ministry%20.html| accessdate=15 October 2016 | publisher=Uganda Ministry of Education and Sports (MES) | title=Ministry of Education and Sports: About the Ministry}} ==Location== The headquarters of the ministry are located in Embassy House, on King George VI Way, at the corner with Parliament Avenue, in the [[Kampala Central Division|Central Division]] of [[Kampala]], Uganda's capital and largest city.{{cite web| title=Location of The Ministry of Education and Sports Headquarters | accessdate=15 October 2016| date=15 October 2016 | url=http://www.education.go.ug/data/smenu/48/Ministry%20Location%20.html | publisher= Uganda Ministry of Education and Sports (MES) | author=MES | location=Kampala}} The coordinates of the ministry headquarters are:0°18'50.0"N, 32°35'15.0"E (Latitude:0.313889; Longitude:32.587500).{{google maps|title=The Geographical Coordinates of the Headquarters of the Uganda Ministry of Education and Sports | accessdate=15 October 2016| url=https://www.google.com/maps/place/0%C2%B018'50.0%22N+32%C2%B035'15.0%22E/@0.3138988,32.5867464,163m/data=!3m1!1e3!4m5!3m4!1s0x0:0x0!8m2!3d0.313889!4d32.5875}} ==Organisational structure== The ministry is overseen by a cabinet minister, currently [[Janet Museveni]], since 6 June 2016.{{cite web|accessdate=15 October 2016| url=http://www.theeastafrican.co.ke/news/Museveni-expands-Cabinet--appoints-wife-to-Education-ministry/-/2558/3236160/-/sjxj9o/-/index.html| date=7 June 2016 |title=Museveni names Cabinet, appoints wife to Education ministry | first=Dicta | last=Asiimwe | newspaper=[[The EastAfrican]]| location=Nairobi}} She is assisted by three ministers of state; (a) [[Rosemary Seninde]] serves as Minister of State for Primary Education, (b) [[John Chrysestom Muyingo]] serves as Minister of State for Secondary Education,{{cite web| date=15 October 2016| url=http://www.parliament.go.ug/index.php/members-of-parliament/cabinet-members | accessdate=15 October 2016 | title=Cabinet Members and Ministers of State | publisher=[[Parliament of Uganda]] (POU)| location=Kampala | author=POU}} and [[Charles Bakkabulindi]] serves as Minister of State for sports.{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201607080155.html |title=Uganda: Bakkabulindi Warns First Lady On Opportunists in Sports | newspaper=[[The Observer (Uganda)]] via [[AllAfrica.com]]|date=8 July 2016| location=Kampala | first=Yudaya |last=Nangonzi}} ==Directorates== Administratively, the ministry is divided into three directorates: (a) Directorate of Education Standards,{{cite web|date=18 October 2016|url=http://www.education.go.ug/data/smenu/6/Directorate%20of%20Education%20Standards.html | title=Directorate of Education Standards|author=MES | publisher=Uganda Ministry of Education and Sports (MES) |location=Kampala | accessdate=18 October 2016}} (b) Directorate of Basic and Secondary Education,{{cite web|date=18 October 2016|accessdate=18 October 2016 | url=http://www.education.go.ug/data/smenu/7/Directorate%20of%20Basic%20and%20Secondary%20Education.html | title=Directorate of Basic and Secondary Education |author=MES | publisher=Uganda Ministry of Education and Sports (MES) | location=Kampala}} and (c) Directorate of Higher, Technical and Vocational Education and Training.{{cite web|accessdate=18 October 2016 | url=http://www.education.go.ug/data/smenu/8/Directorate%20of%20HTVET.html| date=18 October 2016 | title=Directorate of Higher, Technical and Vocational Education and Training | publisher=Uganda Ministry of Education and Sports (MES) | location=Kampala | author=MES}} ==Departments== The ministry is further subdivided into the following departments: (1) Finance and Administration,{{cite web| accessdate=18 October 2016 | author=MES |publisher=Uganda Ministry of Education and Sports (MES) | url=http://www.education.go.ug/data/smenu/9/Finance%20and%20Administration.html| title= Department of Finance and Administration | location=Kampala | date=18 October 2016}} (2) Department of Education Planning,{{cite web| accessdate=18 October 2016 | author=MES | publisher=Uganda Ministry of Education and Sports (MES) |title= Education Planning Department | date=18 October 2016|location=Kampala| url=http://www.education.go.ug/data/smenu/9/Finance%20and%20Administration.html}} (3) Department of Pre-Primary and Primary Education,{{cite web| url=http://www.education.go.ug/data/smenu/11/Pre-Primary%20and%20Primary.html | title=Pre-Primary and Primary Education Department | publisher=Uganda Ministry of Education and Sports (MES) | date=18 October 2016| location=Kampala| accessdate=18 October 2016 | author=MES}} (4) Department of Secondary Education,{{cite web| url=http://www.education.go.ug/data/smenu/12/Secondary%20Education.html | title=Department of Secondary Education | publisher=Ugandan Ministry of Education and Sports (MES) | author=MES | location=Kampala |date=18 October 2016|accessdate=18 October 2016}} (5) Department of Higher Education,{{cite web| date=18 October 2016| accessdate=18 October 2016| url=http://www.education.go.ug/data/smenu/13/Higher%20Education.html | title=Department of Higher Education | publisher=Ugandan Ministry of Education and Sports (MES) | author=MES | location=Kampala}} (6) Department of Private Schools and Institutions,{{cite web| url=http://www.education.go.ug/data/smenu/50/Private%20Schools%20and%20Institutions.html| date=18 October 2016 |title= Department of Private Schools and Institutions | publisher=Ugandan Ministry of Education and Sports (MES) | author=MES | location=Kampala|accessdate=18 October 2016}} (7) Department of Teacher Education,{{cite web|accessdate=18 October 2016 | url=http://www.education.go.ug/data/smenu/14/Teacher%20Education.html | date=18 October 2016 | title=Department of Teacher Education | last=MES | publisher=Uganda Ministry of Education and Sports (MES) | location=Kampala}} (8) Department of Special Needs and Inclusive Education, {{cite web|accessdate=18 October 2016 | location=Kampala| date=18 October 2016 | url=http://www.education.go.ug/data/smenu/15/Special%20Needs%20and%20Inclusive%20Education%20.html | title=Department of Special Needs and Inclusive Education | publisher=Uganda Ministry of Education and Sports (MES)| last=MES}} (9) Department of Business, Technical and Vocational Education,{{cite web|accessdate=18 October 2016 | location=Kampala| date=18 October 2016 |url=http://www.education.go.ug/data/smenu/16/BTVET.html | title=Department of Business, Technical and Vocational Education (BTVET) | publisher=Uganda Ministry of Education and Sports (MES)| last=MES}} (10) Department of Guidance and Counselling,{{cite web|accessdate=18 October 2016 | location=Kampala| date=18 October 2016 | last=MES| url=http://www.education.go.ug/data/smenu/18/Guidance%20and%20Counselling.html | title=Department of Guidance and Counselling| publisher=Uganda Ministry of Education and Sports (MES)}} (11) Department of Physical Education and Sports,{{cite web|accessdate=18 October 2016 | location=Kampala| date=18 October 2016 | last=MES | title=Department of Physical Education and Sports| publisher=Uganda Ministry of Education and Sports (MES) | url=http://www.education.go.ug/data/smenu/19/Physical%20Education%20and%20Sports.html}} (12) HIV/AIDS Unit{{cite web|accessdate=18 October 2016 | location=Kampala| date=18 October 2016 | last=MES | title=HIV/AIDS Unit | publisher=Uganda Ministry of Education and Sports (MES) | url=http://www.education.go.ug/data/smenu/20/HIV/AIDS%20Unit.html}} and (13) Gender Unit.{{cite web|accessdate=18 October 2016 |last=MES | url=http://www.education.go.ug/data/smenu/49/Gender%20Unit.html | location=Kampala| date=18 October 2016 | title=Gender Unit | publisher=Uganda Ministry of Education and Sports (MES)}} ==See also== * [[Politics of Uganda]] * [[Cabinet of Uganda]] * [[Parliament of Uganda]] * [[Education in Uganda]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.education.go.ug/}} {{coord|00|18|50|N|32|35|15|E|display=title}} [[Category:Government ministries of Uganda]] [[Category:Education in Uganda]] [[Category:Kampala]] [[Category:Education ministries]] [[Category:Sports ministries]]

revision.comment: http→https for [[Google Books]] and [[Google News]] using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
'''Mothers Organized for Moral Stability''', also known as '''MOMS''', was a socially conservative American organization that arose in [[Orange County, California]] in the 1960s and whose primary goal was to counter the cultural trend at the time towards allowing sexual education and techniques for birth control to be taught in public schools.<ref name="Farber2012">{{cite book|author=David Farber|title=The Rise and Fall of Modern American Conservatism: A Short History|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WQRgq650bZYC&pg=PA154|accessdate=4 September 2013|date=26 August 2012|publisher=Princeton University |isbn=978-1-4008-3429-7|page=154}}</ref> It was one of a number of such acronym-based conservative American organizations and shared a political agenda with groups such as SOS ("Sanity on Sex"), POSSE ("Parents Opposed to Sex and Sensitivity Education"), PAUSE ("Parents Against Unconstitutional Sex Education"), ACRE ("Associated Citizens for Responsible Education"), POPE ("Parents for Orthodoxy in Parochial Education"), and CHIDE ("Committee to Halt Indoctrination and Demoralization in Education") among many others.<ref name="BruessSchroeder2013">{{cite book|author1=Clint E. Bruess|author2=Elizabeth Schroeder|title=Sexuality Education Theory and Practice|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WWFW6-kkAVoC&pg=PA43|accessdate=4 September 2013|date=30 May 2013|publisher=Jones & Bartlett |isbn=978-1-4496-4928-9|page=43}}</ref>
==History== MOMS was largely an organized reaction by conservative residents of the county to the [[Anaheim Union High School District]]'s family life and sex education course. The school district had implemented a sex education course in 1965 with little resistance. Three years later, in 1968, a homemaker named [[Eleanor Howe]], whose son was enrolled at one of the district's schools, got wind of the curriculum and began organizing a network of like-minded mothers to confront the school board. The members of this group flocked to a meeting of the school board and quoted material from a pamphlet, ''[[Is the Schoolhouse the Proper Place to Teach Raw Sex?]]'', which had recently been published by [[Billy James Hargis]]'s Christian Crusade and demanded that the course be halted immediately. They also stated their firm belief, based on the film [[Pavlov's Children]] produced by members of the political Radical Right who saw the US as locked in conflict between Christian-based traditional values and Communist subversive "new" values, that the course was the result of a Soviet communist conspiracy orchestrated through the [[United Nations]] to make American youth amenable to totalitarian dictatorship.<ref name="Winters2012">{{cite book|author=Michael Sean Winters|title=God's Right Hand: How Jerry Falwell Made God a Republican and Baptized the American Right|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mZCLmJu546oC&pg=PT18|accessdate=4 September 2013|date=17 January 2012|publisher=HarperCollins|isbn=978-0-06-209872-6|page=18}}</ref> Within a year they had replaced the elected members of the board with their political allies, and the sex education program at A.U.H.S.D. was dispensed with.<ref name="Corngold2008">{{cite book|author=Josh Corngold|title=Toleration, Parents' Rights, and Children's Autonomy: The Case of Sex Education|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ixJCExcQLXoC&pg=PA149|accessdate=4 September 2013|year=2008|publisher=ProQuest|isbn=978-0-549-85273-5|pages=149–150}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Opposition to sex education]] [[Category:Education in Orange County, California]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2014}} {{Use British English|date=February 2014}} {{Infobox recurring event | name = National Astronomy Week (NAW) | native_name = | logo = | logo_caption = | image = | caption = | status = Active | genre = Astronomy-related events and competitions | date = | begins = | ends = | frequency = As per notable events;
Duration: 1 Week | venue = | location = | country = [[United Kingdom]] | years_active = 33 | first = {{Start date|1981}} | founder_name = | last = | prev = 2014 | next = Not yet announced | participants = Observed by [[Astronomer]]s and astronomy enthusiasts | attendance = | area = | budget = | patron = | organised = | filing = | people = | member = | website = {{URL|http://astronomyweek.org.uk}} | footnotes = }} '''National Astronomy Week''' (NAW) is an event held every few years in the [[United Kingdom]] to promote public awareness of astronomy by celebrating notable astronomical events. ==Activities== During the week, astronomy societies, planetaria, schools, universities and other organisations from all over the UK organise events to promote interest in, and knowledge of, astronomy. The organisers promote the week using extensive contacts with the media and all the major UK astronomical organisations, many of whom provide funding. Events range from talks, visits and in particular the opportunity for children and adults alike to observe the sky through a range of equipment. The 2014 event is described in ''[[Astronomy & Geophysics]]'' magazine.{{cite journal |title=Target Jupiter: National Astronomy Week 2014 |url=http://astrogeo.oxfordjournals.org/content/54/2/2.5.2.extract |journal=Astronomy & Geophysics |year=2013 |publisher=astrogeo.oxfordjournals |volume=54 |issue=2 |pages=2 |doi=10.1093/astrogeo/att006 |accessdate=1 January 2014}} ===History=== The need for National Astronomy Week (NAW) was first defined in the late 1970s. A group of both professional and amateur astronomers as well as teachers and educators was formed to define and run the first ever event. NAW was proposed in 1979 and a steering committee was set up in 1980. Since then a total of seven events have run as listed below. {| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto;" |+ Timeline of NAW events |-style="text-align:center;" | '''Sr.''' | '''Year''' | '''Notes''' | '''Reference''' |- | style="text-align:center;"| 1 | style="text-align:center;"| 1981 | To commemorate the 200th anniversary of the discovery of Uranus. | |- | style="text-align:center;"| 2 | style="text-align:center;"| 1985 | Return of [[Halley’s Comet]]. | |- | style="text-align:center;"| 3 | style="text-align:center;"| 1990 | To commemorate the centenary of the [[British Astronomical Association]]. | |- | style="text-align:center;"| 4 | style="text-align:center;"| 1996 | To commemorate the 150th anniversary of the discovery of Neptune. | |- | style="text-align:center;"| 5 | style="text-align:center;"| 2003 | To coincide with arguable the closest approach of Mars for 60,000 years. | |- | style="text-align:center;"| 6 | style="text-align:center;"| 2009 | To celebrate the 400th anniversary of [[Thomas Harriot]]'s reputed first use of the telescope for astronomical purposes.
It was during the [[International Year of Astronomy]] in 2009 as a major event organised by the steering committee at Syon House | {{cite web |url=http://telescope400.org.uk/ |title=Syon Park: Sunday 26th July 2009 |author= |website=telescope400.org.uk |publisher=National Astronomy Week |accessdate=24 December 2013}} |- | style="text-align:center;"| 7 | style="text-align:center;"| 2014 | To celebrate [[Jupiter]] attaining its highest possible point in the northern hemisphere night skies for 12 years. | {{cite web |url=http://www.astronomyweek.org.uk |title=Coming! 1st to 8th March 2014 |author=|website=astronomyweek.org.uk |publisher=NAW |accessdate=24 December 2013}} |} ===2014=== The seventh event, named "Target Jupiter", ran from 1–8 March 2014. Jupiter was at a very high position in the sky, the best that will be achieved for many years. Observing conditions were generally well above average. More than 200 events were run across the UK. Participating organisations included Astronomy Societies, Schools, Universities, and Scouts/Guides. The details are listed on the National Astronomy Week website.{{cite web |url=http://www.astronomyweek.org.uk |title=Coming! 1st to 8th March 2014 |author=|website=astronomyweek.org.uk |publisher=NAW |accessdate=24 December 2013}} The event was widely announced in the UK, for example in ''[[Astronomy & Geophysics]]'' magazine,{{cite journal |title=Target Jupiter: National Astronomy Week 2014 |url=http://astrogeo.oxfordjournals.org/content/54/2/2.5.2.extract |journal=Astronomy & Geophysics |year=2013 |publisher=astrogeo.oxfordjournals |volume=54 |issue=2 |pages=2 |doi=10.1093/astrogeo/att006 |accessdate=24 December 2013}} and there is also information on the NAW Twitter page[https://twitter.com/NAW2014NAW2014 NAW2014 on Twitter] and on Facebook.[https://www.facebook.com/astronomyweek NAW2014 on Facebook] A special event radio station, call sign GB1NAW, transmitted from [[Lockyer Observatory and Planetarium|Lockyer Technology Centre]] during National Astronomy Week (and the week preceding), between 7.060 MHz and 7.200 MHz LSB (Lower Side Band) during daylight hours and between 3.600 MHz and 3.800 MHz LSB after dusk. ==Sponsorship and funding== National Astronomy Week is sponsored (and funded) by some of the most significant science organisations in the UK, including the [[Science & Technology Facilities Council]] and the [[Royal Astronomical Society]]. ==See also== {{Portal|Astronomy|Solar System|Spaceflight}} * [[Earth Hour]] * [[Earth Day]] * [[100 Hours of Astronomy]] (100HA) * [[National Dark-Sky Week]] (NDSW) * [[Astronomy Day]] *[[White House Astronomy Night]] ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=25em}} ==External links== * {{official website|http://astronomyweek.org.uk}} * [http://www.stfc.ac.uk/ Science & Technologies Facilities Council] * [http://www.ras.org.uk Royal Astronomical Society] * [http://www.qrz.com/db/GB1NAW GB1NAW Web page] [[Category:Astronomy education events]] [[Category:Astronomy in the United Kingdom]]

page.title: National Museum Institute of the History of Art, Conservation and Museology

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox university | name = National Museum Institute of the History of Art, Conservation and Museology | native_name = | image_name = Logo of National Museum Institute of the History of Art, Conservation and Museology.jpg | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = | latin_name = | punch line = | mottoeng = | established = 27 January 1989 | closed = | type = Registered Society | affiliation = | endowment = | officer_in_charge = | chairman = | chancellor = | president = | director_general = | total_staff = | administrative_staff = | students = | scientists = | city = [[Janpath]] | state = [[New Delhi]] | province = [[New Delhi]] | country = [[India]] | coor = {{Coord|77|12|32|N|28|36|50|E|}} | campus = National Museum Campus | former_names = | free_label = | free = | colors = | colours = | athletics = | sports = | nickname = NMIHACM<ref name="Acronym finder">{{cite web | url=http://www.acronymfinder.com/National-Museum-Institute-of-History-of-Art-Conservation-Museology-(India)-(NMIHACM).html | title=Acronym finder | publisher=Acronym finder | date=2014 | accessdate=25 November 2014}}</ref> | mascot = | affiliations = [[Deemed University]] | budget = | website = {{URL|http://nmi.gov.in|NMIHACM}} | logo = | footnotes = }} [[File:Nalanda.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Nalanda]] is considered one of the first great universities in recorded history. It was the centre of [[Buddhism|Buddhist]] learning and research in the world from 450 to 1193 CE.]] '''The National Museum Institute of the History of Art, Conservation and Museology (NMIHACM)''' is an autonomous institute, a seat of higher education in the fields of [[History]], [[Conservation (cultural heritage)|Conservation]] and [[Museology]] under the [[Ministry of Culture (India)|Ministry of Culture]], [[Government of India]]. The Institute is a ''[[deemed university]]''<ref name="Deemed University">{{cite web | url=http://www.archive.india.gov.in/knowindia/culture_heritage.php?id=85 | title=Deemed University | publisher=Deemed University | date=2014 | accessdate=25 November 2014}}</ref> and is located at [[Janpath]], New Delhi, within the premises of [[National Museum, New Delhi|National Museum]], New Delhi.<ref name="Mingle Box">{{cite web | url=http://www.minglebox.com/college/National-Museum-Institute-Delhi | title=Mingle Box | publisher=Mingle Box | date=2014 | accessdate=25 November 2014}}</ref>
== Profile == [[File:Mohenjo-daro Priesterkönig.jpeg|thumb|left|150px|<center>"Priest King" of [[Indus Valley Civilisation]]</center>]] The National Museum Institute of the History of Art, Conservation and Museology was established on 27 January 1989, under the Societies Registration Act by the Ministry of Culture, Government of India for providing facilities for advanced studies and research in the field of art and cultural heritage. The Institute was given the status of a deemed university by the [[Ministry of Human Resource Development (India)|Ministry of Human Resource Development]] on 28 April 1989.{{fact|date=October 2018}}
NMIHACM has now positioned itself as the premier institute of its kind in India and is located within the premises of the National Museum in New Delhi. The Institute has been offering study opportunities at the diploma, Masters and Doctoral levels since 1985 on various aspects such as [[history]], [[Conservation (cultural heritage)|conservation]] and restoration and [[museology]].{{fact|date=October 2018}}
== Objectives == The main objectives of NMI are set as:<ref name="Deemed University" /> * Providing for various courses of study, training and research in different branches of History of art, Museology, Conservation, etc. * Collaborating with other national institutions dealing with cultural property, like the National Museum, Archaeological Survey of India, Anthropological Survey of India, National Gallery of Modern Art, National Archives of India and the like, in order to share the material, curatorial / technical expertise and facilities; Interacting on a continuing basis at the national level to improve standards of teaching in the above fields. * Providing academic guidance and leadership. * Publishing such works of the Institute as may have contributed substantially to the fields of specialization.
== Departments == [[File:Conservation at the Church of Suceviţa.jpg|right|thumb|<center>Restoration by physical chemical means</center>]] The Institute's functions are broadly divided into three areas and each area is managed by a dedicated department.
'''History of Art''': The Department of History of Art offers educational opportunities in Indian, Asian and Western Art.
'''Conservation''': The Department of Conservation is the platform of NMIHACM for imparting training on conservation of art and cultural heritage.
'''Museology''': The Department of Museology controls the curriculum on studies on Museology.
==Projects== [[File:Family Roerich.JPG|thumb|right|150px|<center>Roerich's family. (Kullu valley, India).</center>]] NMIHACM undertakes various projects with regard to heritage conservation across the country;<ref name="Maps of India">{{cite web | url=http://www.mapsofindia.com/my-india/government/a-complete-catalogue-of-the-diverse-art-forms-of-india | title=Maps of India | publisher=Maps of India | date=2014 | accessdate=25 November 2014}}</ref> some of them are: * Documentation of Intangible Cultural Heritage: Based on inventories in the [[Ladakh]] and Western Uttar Pradesh Region.<ref name="Western Uttar Pradesh Meerut Region">{{cite web | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pS3jas3n49M | title=Western Uttar Pradesh Meerut Region | publisher=YouTube | date=2014 | accessdate=25 November 2014}}</ref><ref name="Stone carver">{{cite web | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lIIaLl07Jws | title=Stone carver | publisher=YouTube | date=2014 | accessdate=25 November 2014}}</ref><ref name="Weaver">{{cite web | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NT-t3HYc1bU | title=Weaver | publisher=YouTube | date=2014 | accessdate=25 November 2014}}</ref> * A school-based project for establishing ''Museum Corners'' in schools of [[Nubra Valley|Nubra]], Thangtse and Khaltsa regions of Ladakh and [[Meerut]] in Western Uttar Pradesh.<ref name="Western Uttar Pradesh Meerut Region" /> * ''Yuva Saathi'': An action research project involving young volunteers aimed at the young visitors of the [[National Museum, New Delhi|National Museum]]. * ''Museum extends to Hospital'': Installation of paintings in the paedatric wards of the [[All India Institute of Medical Sciences]] (AIIMS), New Delhi. * ''Documentation of Nine Masters'': Digital documentation of the works of [[Nicholas Roerich]], the Russian painter who lived in India. * ''Museum Accessibility and Visitor Studies'': A survey of the main art museums in India such as the National Museum, the [[National Gallery of Modern Art, Mumbai|National Gallery of Modern Art]] and the Handicrafts and Textile Museum. * ''Indian Life and Landscapes by Western Artists'': Visitor access studies of the exhibition conducted at Chatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Vastu Sanghralaya, Mumbai, 27 January 2009.
==Exhibitions== [[File:August-Hermann-Francke.jpg|thumb|100px|<center>August Hermann Francke</center>]] [[File:Preventive Conservation - Serra da Capivara.jpg|right|thumb|300px|<center>Preventive conservation on a rock wall</center>]] [[File:IMG 6170 - MI - Sant'Eustorgio - Sottocoro - Restauratrice - Foto Giovanni Dall'Orto - 1-Mar-2007.jpg|thumb|200px|right|A restorer at work.]] NMIHACM, through its Department of Museology, has organised several exhibitions, covering various topics under History and conservation. * ''First Frames - In the Footsteps of Early Explorers'' : A month long photo exhibition on Western Himalayas, based on the explorations of Li Gotami, [[Lama Anagarika Govinda]], and [[August Hermann Francke]] on 1 September 2012. * ''Nako – Living cultural heritage in the Western Himalayas'' : Photo exhibition in collaboration with the Department of Museology and Conservation and Austria Embassy on 18 March 2011. * ''Astitav- a quest for Identity'' : Exhibition jointly organised at Children's Museum, [[Siri Fort]], New Delhi with the [[Archaeological Survey of India]] in August 2008. * ''Astitav- a Search for Our Identity'' : Exhibition on monuments and their degradation on February 2008. * Exhibition of the photo collections of J. Ph. Vogel, Kern Institute, [[Leiden]] on March 2008. * ''Prabhava'' Photo and Object Exhibition on Indian art and ots foreign influences in 2004. * ''Ehasas: Senses and Images'' : Exhibition for the visually impaired in November 2002.
==Courses== NMIHACM offers three courses at Masters level; MA in History of Arts, MA in Conservation and MA in Museology. All the three programs are two year full-time Masters courses and offer higher studies in the respective areas of study.<ref name="Mingle Box" /><ref name="Dinamalar">{{cite web | url=http://origin-kalvimalar.dinamalar.com/news-details.asp?id=2453&cat=8 | title=Dinamalar | publisher=Dinamalar | date=2014 | accessdate=25 November 2014}}</ref><ref name="Success CD">{{cite web | url=http://www.successcds.net/Admission-Notification/National-Museum-Institute-of-History-of-Art-Conservation-Museology-New-Delhi.html | title=Success CD | publisher=Success CD | date=2014 | accessdate=25 November 2014}}</ref> A limited number of Government scholarships are available for all the courses.<ref name="Scholarship India">{{cite web | url=http://www.scholarshipsinindia.com/national_museum_institute_university.html | title=Scholarship India | publisher=Scholarship India | date=2014 | accessdate=25 November 2014}}</ref>
NMIHACM offers doctoral research facilities for PhD in:<ref name="India against corruption">{{cite web | url=http://www.indiaagainstcorruption.com/f27/national-museum-institute-university-history-art-ph-d-admissions-2010-a-9661 | title=India against corruption | publisher=India against corruption | date=2014 | accessdate=25 November 2014}}</ref> * Museum Education * Museum Exhibition and Communication * Eco-Museums * Museum Documentation The Institute organises internal and external lecture series and seminars for the research scholars.<ref name="Press Information Bureau">{{cite web | url=http://www.pib.nic.in/newsite/erelease.aspx?relid=94051 | title=Press Information Bureau | publisher=Press Information Bureau | date=2014 | accessdate=25 November 2014}}</ref><ref name="UEA">{{cite web | url=https://www.uea.ac.uk/art-history/news-and-events/south-asian-collections-conference | title=UEA | publisher=UEA | date=2014 | accessdate=25 November 2014}}</ref>
NMIHACM also conducts a few short-term courses on ''India Art and culture'', ''Art Appreciation'' and ''Bhartiya Kalanidhi'' (Hindi Medium).<ref name="Deemed University" /><ref name=autogenerated4>[http://www.delhiinformation.in/education/institutes/nmihacm.html National Museum Institute of History of Art, Conservation & Museology | NMIHACM in Delhi<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Library== NMIHACM has access to a well stocked library maintained at National Museum Institute which is equipped with a fully automated digital library consisting of 68,014 slides, apart from the hard copy collections.<ref name="Global Shiksha 2">{{cite web | url=http://college.globalshiksha.com/National-Museum-Institute/806876550039459#college_details | title=Global Shiksha 2 | publisher=Global Shiksha | date=2014 | accessdate=25 November 2014}}</ref> Many journals subscribed by the library is also accessible to NMIHACM.<ref name=autogenerated4 />
==Publications== The Institute regularly releases important publications on History, conservation and Museology, some of the more notable ones are:<ref name=autogenerated4 /><ref name="NMI">{{cite web | url=http://nmi.gov.in/departmentshoapublications.htm | title=NMI | publisher=NMI | date=2014 | accessdate=25 November 2014}}</ref> * {{cite book | url = https://www.amazon.com/Cultural-Interface-India-Anupa-Pande/dp/812460262X | title = Cultural Interface of India with Asia : Religion, Art and Architecture |author1=Prof. Anupa Pande |author2=Parul Pandya Dhar |lastauthoramp=yes | year = 2004 | publisher = NMIHACM | ISBN = 978-8124602621 }} * {{cite book | url = https://www.amazon.com/God-King-Devaraja-South-Architecture/dp/8189233262 | title = God & King: The Devaraja Cult in South Asian Art & Architecture | author = Prof. Arputharani Sengupta | year = 2005 | publisher = NMIHACM | ISBN = 978-8189233266 }} * {{cite book | url = http://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/restoration-of-indian-miniature-paintings-abha-nawani/1007925653?ean=9788172112042 | title = Restoration of Indian Miniature Paintings | author = K. K. Gupta | year = 2006 | publisher = NMIHACM | ISBN = 9788172112042 }} * {{cite book | url = https://www.amazon.com/The-Heritage-Haider-Tipu-Sultan/dp/8173053944 | title = The Heritage of Haider Ali and Tipu Sultan: Art and Architecture |author1=Pande, Anupa |author2=Savita Kumari |lastauthoramp=yes | year = 2011 | publisher = NMIHACM | ISBN = 978-8173053948 }} * {{cite book | url = http://www.worldcat.org/title/sanaugavut-inuit-art-from-the-canadian-arctic/oclc/719419294 | title = Sanaugavut: Inuit Art from the Canadian Arctic | author = Lalonde, Christne, Mary Simon and Anupa Pande | year = | publisher = NMIHACM | OCLC = 719419294 }} * {{cite book | url = https://www.amazon.com/Art-Central-Asia-Indian-Subcontinent/dp/8173053472 | title = The Art of Central Asia and the Indian Subcontinent in Cross - Cultural Perspective | author = Pande, Anupa | year = 2009 | publisher = NMIHACM | ISBN = 978-8173053474 }} * {{cite book | url = | title = Indus Valley Civilisation | author = Pant, G.N. | year = | publisher = NMIHACM | ISBN = }} * {{cite book | url = | title = India and the Indus Civilisation |author1=Joshi, J.P. |author2=R. S. Bisht |lastauthoramp=yes | year = 1994 | publisher = NMIHACM | ISBN = }} * {{cite book | url = | title = The Mauryan Art (Indian Art of the third century BC) | author = Kaur, Jasvinder | year = 1992 | publisher = NMIHACM | ISBN = }}
== Example of an archaeological discovery and restoration of a mural painting == {{main|Conservation (cultural heritage)}} <gallery perrow="3" widths="180" heights="270"> Image:St amant roche savine 3 (2).jpg|<center>First archaeological search in the 19th-century layer by French archaeologist and restorer [[Yves Morvan]]</center> Image:St amant roche savine 1 (2).jpg|<center>Painting of the 15th century cleared before restoration</center> Image:St amant roche savine 8.jpg|<center>Painting after restoration</center> </gallery>
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == * [https://www.google.com/culturalinstitute/collection/national-museum-delhi?projectId=art-project Reference on Google Info] * [http://www.indiacollegesearch.com/university/National_Museum_Institute_of_History_of_Art_Conservation_and_Museology Reference on India College Search] * [http://college.globalshiksha.com/National-Museum-Institute/806876550039459#college_details Profile on Global Shiksha] * [http://www.greatarchaeology.com/museum_details.php?museum=National_Museum Reference on Great Archeology site] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ThuIHOwA31U on YouTube] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PuNSbxcuKdc on YouTube] * [http://download.5law.org/m/museology-pdf-s6/ Further reading on Museology]
==Further reading== * {{cite book | url = | title = Handbook of Universities |author1=Ashish Kumar |author2=Ameeta Gupta | year = 2006 | publisher = Atlantic Publishers & Distributors | ISBN = 9788126906086 }}

{{Infobox union | name = National Union of Women Teachers | motto = Pass on the sacred flame | image = File:National_Union_of_Women_Teachers_logo.jpg | founded = 27 April 1904 | predecessor = [[National Union of Teachers]] | dissolved_date = 1961 | dissolved_state = Dissolved | members = 21,000 (1920)<ref name="doughan">{{cite book|last1=Doughan|first1=David|last2=Gordon|first2=Peter|title=Dictionary of British Women's Organisations, 1825-1960|date=2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=1136897704|page=110}}</ref> | journal = ''The Woman Teacher''<ref name="doughan" /> | country = United Kingdom | head = | affiliation = | people = <!-- {{ubl}} if multiple --> | office = 41 [[Cromwell Road]], [[South Kensington]] | footnotes = }}
The '''National Union of Women Teachers''' ('''NUWT''') was a trade union representing women [[schoolteacher]]s in Great Britain. It originated in 1904 as a campaign for equal pay for equal work, and dissolved in 1961, when this was achieved.
==History== Women teachers in the [[National Union of Teachers]] (NUT) first formed a Ladies' Committee in 1896. In 1900, this became a standing committee, consisting of the women members of the executive of the union, and some male executive members in an "ex officio" role. However, the committee focused on recruitment drives and, for example, in 1906 refused to sign a petition for [[women's suffrage]]. The union's journal, ''Board Teacher'', was opposed to equal pay for women teachers, but the Ladies' Committee was unwilling to campaign on the issue. This inspired a small number of members to form the '''Equal Pay League''' in April 1904.<ref name="copelman">{{cite book|last1=Copelman|first1=Dinah|title=London's Women Teachers: Gender, Class and Feminism, 1870-1930|date=2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=1136094768}}</ref><ref name="mbb">{{cite book|last1=Boussahba-Bravard|first1=Myriam|title=Suffrage Outside Suffragism: Britain 1880-1914|date=2007|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|location=Basingstoke|isbn=9781349544912|pages=205-230}}</ref>
The main founders of the league were L. E. Lane, a London-based teacher who had previously campaigned to equalise payments from the union's benevolent and orphanage funds, and Joseph Tate, based in Birmingham, who became its first honorary secretary. Other founder members included [[Teresa Billington]], who soon became the group's main organiser, and her Manchester branch became the most important section of the organisation. But growth was initially slow, with only 34 members by November, and an effort to pass an equal pay policy at the NUT conference that year was unsuccessful.<ref name="copelman" /><ref name="mbb" />
In 1906 the organisation was renamed the '''National Federation of Women Teachers''', and it adopted a new policy of opposing increases in membership dues for women, on the grounds that they received lower benefits than male members. It successfully sponsored Isabel Cleghorn's campaign to become vice-president of the NUT in 1909. Failing to persuade the NUT to support women's suffrage, many federation members were founders of the [[Women Teachers' Franchise Union]] in 1912.<ref name="copelman" /><ref name="mbb" /> [[Ethel Froud]] became honorary secretary of the federation in 1913, the position being renamed "general secretary" in 1917; she remained in post until 1940.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/48575;jsessionid=F804EEFA86E9D4BA378A40CA01948790|title=Ethel Froud|last=Kean|first=Hilda|website=www.oxforddnb.com|access-date=2017-06-09}}</ref>
By 1916, the federation's membership had grown significantly, and its members had become increasingly frustrated with continuing male control of the NUT. It decided to prepare to break away from the NUT after the conclusion of [[World War I]]. Although the NUT finally adopted a policy of equal pay in 1919, it did not prioritise this during subsequent pay negotiations, and this was the final straw.<ref name="oram">{{cite book|last1=Oram|first1=Alison|title=Women Teachers and Feminist Politics, 1900-39|date=1996|publisher=Manchester University Press|location=Manchester|isbn=0719027594|pages=3, 130}}</ref> In 1920, the federation broke away to form an independent [[trade union]], the "National Union of Women Teachers" (NUWT). From this date, members of the central council of the NUWT were not permitted to hold membership of the NUT. Rank-and-file members were initially permitted to also join the NUT, as the union feared that otherwise its members in rural areas would be isolated. However, the union discouraged joint membership, and prohibited it in 1932.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Partington|first1=Geoffrey|title=Women Teachers in the Twentieth Century in England and Wales|date=1976|publisher=NFER Publishing Company|isbn=0856331007|page=20}}</ref>
The NUWT was a [[feminist]] organisation, maintaining close links with other groups and individuals in the [[Feminist movement]].<ref name="PrenticeTheobald1991">{{cite book|last=King|first=Sara|editor=Alison L. Prentice; Marjorie R. Theobald|title=Women who Taught: Perspectives on the History of Women and Teaching|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-ZvxvBlnMvIC&pg=PA182|year=1991|publisher=University of Toronto Press|isbn=978-0-8020-6785-2|pages=182–201|chapter=Feminists in Teaching: The National Union of Women Teachers, 1920-1945}}</ref> Its main aim was to obtain [[equal pay for women]] but also interested itself in the wide range of issues affecting women teachers including the marriage bar, [[Parental leave|maternity rights]] and family allowances. It was also concerned with [[education]] in its widest sense and took an interest in many issues such as class sizes, [[corporal punishment]], the [[Raising Of School Leaving Age|school leaving age]], teacher training, and wider social and political debates such as [[capital punishment]], the [[minimum wage]] and health policy.
Membership of the union peaked at 8,500 in the mid-1920s, and thereafter gradually declined.<ref name="oram" /> In 1961, when equal pay had been achieved, the union wound up.<ref name="DoughanGordon2014">{{cite book|last1=Doughan|first1=David|last2=Gordon|first2=Peter|title=Dictionary of British Women's Organisations, 1825-1960|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=T423AwAAQBAJ&pg=PA102|year=2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-136-89770-2|page=102|chapter=National Union of Women Teachers}}</ref> Members either joined the NUT or the Association of Assistant Mistresses, while the anti-feminist [[National Association of Schoolmasters]] arranged for the formation of a new [[Union of Women Teachers]].<ref name="ironside">Mike Ironside and Roger Seifert, ''Industrial Relations in Schools'', p.92</ref>
Presidents of the union included [[Emily Phipps]], [[Agnes Dawson]], [[Nancy Stewart Parnell]] and [[Nan McMillan]].
==Secretaries== :1904: Joseph Tate :1913: [[Ethel Froud]] :1941: Muriel Pierotti
==Primary sources== The archive of the National Union of Women Teachers is held in the [http://libguides.ioe.ac.uk/nuwtcollection UCL Institute of Education Archives], and a partial list can be found on the [http://archive.ioe.ac.uk/DServe/dserve.exe?dsqIni=Dserve.ini&dsqApp=Archive&dsqDb=Catalog&dsqCmd=NaviTree.tcl&dsqField=RefNo&dsqItem=UWT#HERE online catalogue].
==Published histories== * [[Kean, Hilda]], ''Deeds Not Words: The lives of suffragette teachers'', Pluto, (London, 1989). * Phipps, Emily, ''A History of the National Union of Women Teachers'', National Union of Women Teachers, (London, 1928). * Pierotti, A.M ''The Story of the National Union of Women’s Teachers'', (London, 1963).
==See also== * [[Equal pay for women]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{UK-trade-union-stub}}

{{Infobox Union| |name = NZEI |country = [[New Zealand]] |affiliation = [[Education International]] |members = 50,000 |full_name = New Zealand Educational Institute Te Riu Roa |native_name = Te Riu Roa |founded = 1883 |current = |head = |dissolved_date = |dissolved_state = |merged_into = |office = [[Wellington]], New Zealand |people = [[Lynda Stuart]], President
[[Paul Goulter]], National Secretary |website = {{url|http://www.nzei.org.nz/}} |footnotes = }} [[File:National Education NZEI Journal 1988 (15353654941).jpg|thumbnail|NZEI's ''National Education'' journal from 1988]] The '''New Zealand Educational Institute''' ('''NZEI''', in Maori: Te Riu Roa) is the largest education [[trade union]] in [[New Zealand]]. It was founded in 1883 and has a membership of 50,000.http://www.nzei.org.nz/NZEI/Aboutus/NZEI/About-Us/Aboutus.aspx ==History == The NZEI was founded by a merger of district institutes of teachers in 1883{{cite encyclopedia |title=Teachers' Organisations — Primary |first= |last= |url= https://teara.govt.nz/en/1966/education-present-administrative-pattern/page-6 |encyclopedia=An Encyclopaedia of New Zealand |date=1966 |publisher= |access-date=19 August 2018}} at a meeting in [[Christchurch]]. It quickly became the nationwide voice of primary school teachers. Since the 1994 merger with the [[Combined Early Childhood Union of Aotearoa]] (CECUA) it has also represented teachers in early childhood centres. Since the major New Zealand employment law changes in the 1980s and 1990s,{{cite encyclopedia |title=Unions and employee organisations - Unions after 1960 |first=Erik |last=Olssen |url= https://teara.govt.nz/en/unions-and-employee-organisations/page-7 |encyclopedia=Te Ara – the Encyclopedia of New Zealand |date=11 March 2010 |publisher= |access-date=19 August 2018}} the NZEI negotiates the more than twenty collective agreements across the two sectors, including principals, teachers, support staff, [[te reo Maori]] immersion staff and Ministerial staff.https://nzei.org.nz/NZEI/Aboutus.aspx?About_Us=3 == Early childhood education == Due to the relatively fragmented history and nature of early childhood education in New Zealand, the largest number of collective agreements negotiated by the NZEI are in this sector. == Primary schools == Primary staff and principals are on separate collective agreements, with separate agreements for area (rural) staff and principals, but these are negotiated together. == Strikes == [[File:Jacinda Ardern at NZEI Te Riu Roa stike rally on the steps of parliament 15th August 2018.jpg|thumb|left|Prime Minister [[Jacinda Ardern]] at NZEI Te Riu Roa strike rally on the steps of parliament 15 August 2018]] The NZEI has [[Strike action|struck]] four times since it was founded in 1883.{{cite news |title=Teachers' strike today: School's out - All you need to know |first= |last= |url= https://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=12106964 |newspaper=The New Zealand Herald |date=15 August 2018 |accessdate=19 August 2018}} [[File:Placards at NZEI Te Riu Roa stike rally on the steps of parliament 15th August 2018.jpg|thumb|right|Placards at NZEI Te Riu Roa strike rally on the steps of parliament 15 August 2018. The placards read "We're not going to take it ANYMORE", "It's time to value teachers" and "iTeach, there's no app for that".]] In 1991 members struck (unsuccessfully) as part of wider industrial and union action against the [[Employment Contracts Act 1991]], which lead to significant changes in New Zealand employment relations.https://teara.govt.nz/en/strikes-and-labour-disputes/page-10 Members struck in 1994 and 1995 to successfully achieve pay parity with the [[Post Primary Teachers' Association]], their colleagues in secondary schooling. This related pay scales to the teachers' qualifications.https://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=2350693 Members struck in 2018 as part of the negotiation round with the [[Sixth Labour Government of New Zealand]]. Rallies and marches were held in the major cities. == References == {{Reflist}} == Further reading == * [http://heritage.nzei.org.nz/nodes/view/2890 NZEI 100, An account of the New Zealand Educational Institute, 1883 - 1983] == External links == {{commons category|New Zealand Educational Institute}} {{Portal|Organized labour}} * [http://www.nzei.org.nz/ NZEI] official site *{{url|http://www.standupforkids.org.nz/}} *{{url|http://www.beststart.org.nz/}} *{{url|http://heritage.nzei.org.nz/}} [[Category:Education International]] [[Category:Education trade unions]] [[Category:Trade unions in New Zealand]] [[Category:Trade unions established in 1883]]

revision.comment: /* Criticism */ On closer reading, that quote is not a criticism of Coughlin. Rather, it is a criticism of the Navy's handling of a different officer's dismissal. Webb's speech expresses no opinion about the validity or otherwise of Coughlin's complaint. As such, I have removed the quote. Since there is nothing left in the section, I have also removed the section.
revision.text:
{{infobox person | name = Paula Coughlin | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1962}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | nationality =American | other_names = Paula Puopolo | known_for = | occupation = Naval officer, pilot
Yoga instructor }} '''Paula Coughlin''' was a [[lieutenant]] and naval aviator in the [[United States Navy]]. She was a [[whistleblower]] who played a role in opening investigations into what was known as the [[Tailhook scandal]]. {{cite news |url = http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1993-04-23/news/1993113135_1_navy-coughlin-tailhook |title = For Tailhook scandal whistle-blower, wait ends today with release of report |publisher = [[Baltimore Sun]] |date = 1993-04-23 |author = Los Angeles Times |accessdate = 2010-08-23 |quote = For Lt. Paula Coughlin, the naval aviator who blew the whistle on sexual assaults at the 1991 Tailhook Association, the waiting ends today, when the Defense Department publicly releases its investigation of the now-infamous party in Las Vegas. |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Farticles.baltimoresun.com%2F1993-04-23%2Fnews%2F1993113135_1_navy-coughlin-tailhook&date=2010-08-23 |archivedate = 2010-08-23 |df = }} {{cite news | url=http://magazine.wsj.com/features/second-chapter/from-navy-whistleblower-to-warrior-pose/ | title=From Tailhook Whistleblower to Warrior Pose | publisher=[[Wall Street Journal]] | date=2009-04-30 | first=David |last= Knowles | accessdate=2010-08-23 | quote= }} {{cite news |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/entertainment/1995/05/22/1995-05-22_stars_brighten__tailhook_.html |title=Stars brighten 'tailhook' |publisher=[[New York Daily News]] |date=1995-05-22 |first=Eric |last=Mink |accessdate=2010-08-23 |quote=Neither the first woman assaulted at the annual gatherings known as Tailhook conventions, nor the only one assaulted that year, Coughlin was the first to press the issue afterwards and keep pressing until action was taken. }}{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} {{cite news |url = https://www.nytimes.com/1994/10/04/us/tailhook-whistle-blower-recalls-attack.html?scp=1&sq=Navy%20rape%20gang%20vegas&st=cse |title = Tailhook Whistle-Blower Recalls Attack |publisher = [[New York Times]] |date = 1994-10-04 |first = Kenneth B. |last = Noble |accessdate = 2010-08-23 |quote = 'I felt that if I didn't make it off the floor, I was sure I was going to be gang raped,' said the former officer, Paula A. Coughlin, describing the scene at the convention in 1991 of the Tailhook Association, an independent group of retired and active naval aviators. Ms. Coughlin was among several dozen women who Navy investigators determined were groped or fondled by drunken male aviators in a crowded third-floor "gantlet" on the final day of the convention. |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F1994%2F10%2F04%2Fus%2Ftailhook-whistle-blower-recalls-attack.html%3Fscp%3D1%26sq%3DNavy%2520rape%2520gang%2520vegas%26st%3Dcse&date=2010-08-23 |archivedate = 2010-08-23 |df = }} Coughlin attended [[Old Dominion University]], where she joined the Reserve Officer Training Corps. She joined the navy in 1984 and became a helicopter pilot.{{cite book|last=Sherrow|first=Victoria|title=Women and the military: an encyclopedia|url=https://books.google.com/books?ei=KTZ1TKPwOMSnOPKozMYG&ct=result&id=5JkgAQAAIAAJ&dq=%22Paula+coughlin%22+%22old+dominion+university%22&q=%22old+dominion+university%22#search_anchor|year=1996|publisher=ABC-CLIO|page=82}} She attended the Tailhook conference in September 1991, organized by former navy aviators at the [[Las Vegas Hilton]]. Many of the attendees got raucously drunk. Coughlin was one of the first female attendees who reported being indecently assaulted by male attendees. Coughlin testified she feared being gang-raped when she was forced to "[[Running the gauntlet#Military custom|run the gauntlet]]". She had reported the incident to senior officers, but after a lack of progress due to "closing ranks and obfuscation," she went public in June 1992.{{cite news|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1316/is_n9_v24/ai_12530386/pg_1/?tag=content;col1|title=Universal soldier: what Paula Coughlin can teach American women – sexual assault victim demands justice|last=Boo|first=Katherine|date=September 1992|work=Washington Monthly|accessdate=25 August 2010}} The President, [[George H.W. Bush]], met with Coughlin and expressed sympathy with her and promised a full investigation.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/06/28/us/president-meets-female-officer-in-navy-incident.html|title=President Meets Female Officer In Navy Incident|last=Lewis|first=Neil A.|date=28 June 1992|work=New York Times|accessdate=25 August 2010}} Coughlin met with Secretary of Defense [[Dick Cheney]]—who told her he had just fired the [[Secretary of the Navy]], implying it was her fault. She resigned from the Navy in February 1994, after being subject to abuse in retaliation for her allegations.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/02/11/us/tailhook-case-whistle-blower-quits-navy.html|title=Tailhook Case Whistle-Blower Quits Navy|date=11 February 1994|work=New York Times|accessdate=25 August 2010}} She settled out of court with the Tailhook Association in October 1994, and was awarded $5.3 million in damages from the hotel after a jury concluded that the Las Vegas Hilton hotel had been negligent in not providing adequate security at the Tailhook convention.{{cite book|last=Skaine|first=Rosemarie|title=Power and gender: issues in sexual dominance and harassment|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DQ-GNzcfrvAC&pg=PA350|year=1996|publisher=McFarland|isbn=0-7864-0208-3|page=350}} A May 1995 made-for-television movie broadcast on ABC was based on Coughlin's story, though she was not involved in making it. {{cite news | url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0114421/plotsummary | title=She stood alone: The tailhook scandal (made for tv) 1995 | publisher=[[imdb.com]] | accessdate=2010-08-23 | quote= }}{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1995-05-11/news/vl-64727_1_marty-humphreys|title=TV Producer Brings Personal Insight to the Tailhook Scandal|last=Kowalick|first=Vince|date=11 May 1995|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=25 August 2010}} In 2012, Coughlin was speaking for [[Protect Our Defenders]], a nonprofit civil rights organization that supports victims of [[sexual assault in the United States military]]. She was featured in a [[Retro Report]] documentary called [http://www.retroreport.org/video/the-legacy-of-tailhook The Legacy of Tailhook] and the [[Academy Award]]-nominated documentary on the subject, ''[[The Invisible War]]''.Browning, William, (October 24, 2012). [http://jacksonville.com/news/crime/2012-10-24/story/jacksonville-resident-historic-tailhook-military-scandal-keeps-pressure "Jacksonville resident in historic 'Tailhook' military scandal keeps pressure on sex assault issue"], Florida ''Times-Union''. Retrieved 2013-05-14. USA Today on December 5, 2017, in the midst of the 2017 [[Weinstein effect|Harvey Weinstein and Weinstein effect sexual abuse allegations]], reported that women who reported past sexual harassment have suffered purgatory. The first instance in the article was Paula Coughlin who testified against Tailhook, and hasn't been able to find work in the private sector since.Guynn, Jessica, "[https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/business/2017/12/04/sexual-harassment-women-careers/901611001/ Sexual harassment used to cost women their careers. That may be changing.]", ''[[USA Today]]'', 5 December 2017 She now owns and operates a yoga studio in Atlantic Beach, Florida. ==References== {{reflist}} == Further reading== * Zimmerman, Jean. ''Tail Spin: Women at War in the Wake of Tailhook'' (1995) ==External links== *[http://www.oceanyoga.biz/instructor-bios.html Biography on Ocean Yoga site] {{DEFAULTSORT:Coughlin, Paula}} [[Category:United States Navy officers]] [[Category:1962 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American yoga teachers]] [[Category:People from Virginia Beach, Virginia]] [[Category:Old Dominion University alumni]] [[Category:People from Atlantic Beach, Florida]] [[Category:American whistleblowers]] [[Category:Women in the United States Navy]] [[Category:Helicopter pilots]] [[Category:Sexual assault in the United States military]] [[Category:American aviators]] [[Category:Female aviators]] [[Category:Women whistleblowers]]

{{Refimprove|date=January 2009}} '''Pedro "Cuban Pete" Aguilar''' (June 14, 1927 in [[San Juan, Puerto Rico]] – January 13, 2009 in [[Miami, Florida]]<ref name=died>[http://www.sun-sentinel.com/news/local/breakingnews/sfl-bn-0113cubanpete,0,4644214.story "Mambo star 'Cuban Pete' dead"]</ref>) was named "the greatest [[Mambo (dance)|Mambo]] dancer ever" by ''[[Life (magazine)|Life]]'' magazine and the legendary [[Tito Puente]].
Mr. Aguilar received tap-dance training in childhood and had an early career in boxing. He then transitioned to dance; creating a rhythmically complex, visually arresting dancing style that electrified audiences. By his own count he invented 100 signature foot, torso and hand movements with names like the Porpoise, the Shimmy Shimmy and the Prayer.
His nickname, "Cuban Pete," was conferred upon him in 1949 at the famous [[Palladium_Ballroom|Palladium]] dance hall in [[New York City]], in reference to the classic [[Mambo (music)|mambo]] song "Cuban Pete" by [[Desi Arnaz]]. The moniker was endorsed by Mr. Arnaz himself. In the 1950s, Mr. Aguilar and partner Millie Donay appeared at a British command performance before the Queen. They also danced at the White House; for President Dwight Eisenhower and later for President Lyndon Johnson. Mr. Aguilar also appeared on the popular Jackie Gleason Show.
Mr. Aguilar won numerous prizes in Latin dancing during the Mambo era, together with his dance partner [[Millie Donay]]. He is a recipient of many prestigious awards for his work, and is the only Latin dancer recognized in the [[Latin Jazz]] exhibit at the [[Smithsonian Institution]].
Mr. Aguilar made a career as a dancer, teacher and choreographer. He also worked for Warner Brothers in Los Angeles for many years. As a consultant on the 1992 film "The Mambo Kings", he taught Antonio Banderas and Armand Assante to mambo, and can be seen in several of the dance scenes.
In 2000, he collaborated with Edward Villella on the ballet “Mambo No. 2 a.m.,” which had its premiere with the Miami City Ballet.
In 2002, a documentary, ''The Lucky Man'' (also entitled Game Boys) by German film-maker Dieter Weihl, featuring Aguilar, premiered at The Tiburon International Film Festival.
Barbara Craddock was his last dance partner (since 1998) and manager. Aguilar and Craddock were both inducted in the International Latin Music Hall of Fame.
On November 14, 2007 it was announced they were the recipients of the Latin Jazz USA Lifetime Achievement Awards at the 2007/08 Ms. Latina International Pageant, with the presentation on December 22, 2007 at the Manuel Artime Theater in Miami, Florida. They were the first Latin dancers to receive this award.
He died January 13, 2009 from heart failure at Sinai Plaza Rehabilitation & Nursing Center, [[Miami]], [[Florida]]. Aguilar is survived by his daughters Denise Gerard and Petrina Aguilar, son Sean P. Aguilar, granddaughter Gina Gerard and grandson Noah.<ref name=died/>
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == *[http://www.salsapower.com/cubanpete Cuban Pete website] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060513174550/http://www.salsapower.com/interviews/cubanpete.htm An interview with Cuban Pete] *[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/01/22/AR2009012203834.html Dancer, Known as 'Cuban Pete,' Was Considered 'Maestro of the Mambo', Washington Post] *[https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2009/may/24/pedro-cuban-pete-aguilar-obituary Pedro 'Cuban Pete' Aguilar, The Guardian] *[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/16/arts/16aguilar.html?_r=0 Pedro Aguilar, Inventive Mambo Dancer, Dies at 81, New York Times]
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Aguilar, Pedro}} [[Category:1927 births]] [[Category:2009 deaths]] [[Category:Mambo]] [[Category:Puerto Rican dancers]] [[Category:Dance teachers]]

{{other uses of|Praxis}} [[File:Ets-logo.png|thumb|ETS logo]] {{Education in the U.S.}} A '''Praxis test''' is one of a series of [[United States|American]] [[teacher]] [[Professional certification|certification]] [[standardized testing|exams]] written and administered by the [[Educational Testing Service]]. Various Praxis tests are usually required before, during, and after [[teacher training]] courses in the [[United States|U.S.]]
In order to be a teacher in most states in the US, the Praxis test is required. It usually consists of two separate tests, Praxis 1 and 2. In some states, [[alternative teacher certification]] programs allow prospective educators to obtain licensure without taking Praxis tests.
The Praxis I, or '''Pre-Professional Skills Test''' ('''PPST'''), consisted of three exams: reading, writing, and mathematics. On September 1, 2014, ETS transitioned to the Praxis '''"CASE"''' or '''"Core Academic Skills for Educators"''' which also consists of reading, writing, and mathematics exams. These sections can be taken as a combined test or separately. In most colleges and universities, a passing score must be earned for admission to teacher education. In most states, a passing score must be earned before the teacher education graduate can apply for his or her teaching license or certificate.
The Praxis II assessments cover many different subject areas. Each state requires a different combination of Praxis II exams for certification. In many states, these include a content knowledge and a pedagogy exam. In some states, students must pass these exams before being accepted into the [[student teaching]] component of the program. Many states use the Praxis II tests as a way to determine [[highly qualified teachers]] status under the [[No Child Left Behind Act]]. The Praxis II School Counseling specialty exam is used by some states as a licensure requirement to practice professional school counseling.
It replaced the National Teacher Examination (NTE), also administered by ETS.
==List of current Praxis II subject tests== * * Art: Content and Analysis * Art: Content Knowledge * American Sign Language * Biology and General Science * Biology: Content Essays * Biology: Content Knowledge * Braille Proficiency * Business Education: Content Knowledge * Chemistry: Short Word Essays * Chemistry: Content Knowledge * Chemistry, Physics and General Science * Chinese (Mandarin): World Language * Citizenship Education: Content Knowledge * Communication * Cooperative Education * Driver Education * Early Childhood: Content Essays * Early Childhood Education * Earth and Space Sciences: Content Knowledge * Economics * Education of Deaf and Hard of Hearing Students * Education of Young Children * Educational Leadership: Administration and Supervision * Elementary Education: Content Knowledge * Elementary Education: Curriculum, Instruction and Assessment * Elementary Education: Instructional Practice and Applications * Elementary Education: Multiple Subjects * English Language Arts: Content and Analysis * English Language Arts: Content Knowledge * English Language, Literature and Composition: Content and Analysis * English Language, Literature and Composition: Content Knowledge * English Language, Literature and Composition: Pedagogy * English to Speakers of Other Languages * Environmental Education * Family and Consumer Sciences * French: World Language * Fundamental Subjects: Content Knowledge * General Science: Content Essays * General Science: Content Knowledge * Geography * German: World Language * Gifted Education * Government/Political Science * Health and Physical Education: Content Knowledge * Health Education * Interdisciplinary Early Childhood Education * Journalism * Latin * Library Media Specialist * Life Science: Pedagogy * Marketing Education * Mathematics: Content Knowledge * Mathematics: Pedagogy * Middle School: Content Knowledge * Middle School English Language Arts * Middle School Mathematics * Middle School: Multiple Subjects * Middle School Science * Middle School Social Studies * Music: Analysis * Music: Concepts and Processes * Music: Content and Instruction * Music: Content Knowledge * Physical Education: Content and Design * Physical Education: Content Knowledge * Physical Education: Movement Forms - Analysis and Design * Physical Science: Content Knowledge * Physical Science: Pedagogy * Physics: Content Essays * Physics: Content Knowledge * Pre-Kindergarten Education * Principles of Learning and Teaching: Early Childhood * Principles of Learning and Teaching: Grades K-6 * Principles of Learning and Teaching: Grades 5-9 * Principles of Learning and Teaching: Grades 7-12 * Professional School Counselor * Psychology * Reading Across the Curriculum: Elementary * Reading Specialist * Safety/Driver Education * School Guidance and Counseling * School Psychologist * School Social Worker: Content Knowledge * Social Sciences: Content Knowledge * Social Studies: Content and Interpretation * Social Studies: Content Knowledge * Sociology * Spanish: World Language * Special Education: Core Knowledge and Applications * Special Education: Core Knowledge and Mild to Moderate Applications * Special Education: Core Knowledge and Severe to Profound Applications * Special Education: Education of Deaf and Hard of Hearing Students * Special Education: Early Childhood * Special Education: Preschool/Early Childhood * Special Education: Teaching Speech to Students with Language Impairments * Special Education: Teaching Students w/ Behavioral Disorders/Emotional Disturbances * Special Education: Teaching Students w/ Learning Disabilities * Special Education: Teaching Students w/ Mental Retardation * Special Education: Teaching Students w/ Visual Impairments * Speech Communication: Content Knowledge * Speech-Language Pathology * Teaching Foundations: English * Teaching Foundations: Mathematics * Teaching Foundations: Multiple Subjects * Teaching Foundations: Science * Teaching Reading * Teaching Reading: Elementary Education * Technology Education * Vocational General Knowledge * World and U.S. History: Content Knowledge * World Languages Pedagogy
==Individual states that use the Praxis II== * [[Alabama]] * [[Alaska]] * [[Arkansas]] * [[Colorado]] * [[Connecticut]] * [[Delaware]] * [[District of Columbia]] * [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] * [[Guam]] * [[Hawaii]] * [[Idaho]] * [[Indiana]] * [[Iowa]] * [[Kansas]] * [[Kentucky]] * [[Louisiana]] * [[Maryland]] * [[Maine]] * [[Mississippi]] * [[Nebraska]] * [[New Jersey]] * [[New Hampshire]] * [[Nevada]] * [[North Carolina]] * [[North Dakota]] * [[Ohio]] * [[Pennsylvania]] * [[Rhode Island]] * [[South Carolina]] * [[South Dakota]] * [[Tennessee]] * [[Utah]] * [[US Virgin Islands]] * [[Vermont]] * [[Virginia]] * [[West Virginia]] * [[Wisconsin]] * [[Wyoming]]
==Teacher certification examinations in individual states== Examples of states that require teaching candidates to pass their state-specific tests, in lieu of the Praxis: * Alabama (AECTP) * Arizona (AEPA) * California ([[CBEST]] and [[California Subject Examinations for Teachers]], also known as CSET) * Colorado (PLACE) * Florida ([[FTCE]]) * Georgia ([[GACE]]) * Illinois (ILTS) * Massachusetts (MTEL) * Michigan (MTTC) * Minnesota (MTLE) * Missouri (CBASE) * New Mexico (NMTA) * New York (NYSTCE) * Ohio (OAE) * Oklahoma (OGET, OPTE, Subject area) * Oregon (ORELA) * Pennsylvania (PAPA, PECT) * Texas (TExES) * Virginia (RVE) * Washington (WEST-B/WEST-E/NES) * Wisconsin (NES)
==External links== * [http://www.ets.org/praxis The Official Site from ETS] * [[b: Contemporary Educational Psychology|Contemporary Educational Psychology]]—a Wikibook organized to support preparation for the Praxis II test called "Principles of Learning and Teaching" * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100711130904/http://www.theteachercenter.org/testingservices/statetesting/requirements.asp]—List of states that use the Praxis II test.

revision.comment: Product School has 15 campuses. The info was outdated
revision.text:
{{Infobox school | name = Product School | city = {{hlist|[[San Francisco|San Francisco, California]]|[[Silicon Valley|Silicon Valley, California]]|[[New York City|New York City, New York]]|[[Los Angeles|Los Angeles, California]]|[[Santa Monica|Santa Monica, California]]|[[Orange County, California]]}} | schooltype = [[Private school|Private]] | established = 2014 | founder = Carlos González de Villaumbrosia | website = https://www.productschool.com }}
'''Product School''' is a for-profit tech business school founded by Carlos González de Villaumbrosia in 2014<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://angel.co/productschool|title=Product School|website=angel.co|access-date=2017-09-04}}</ref>. The organization provides courses in Product Management, Coding for Managers, Data Analytics for Managers, Blockchain & Cryptocurrencies and Digital Marketing for Managers.
The organization maintains fifteen campuses, located across the United States, Canada and Europe, and also offers their courses online<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.productschool.com/|title=Home - Product School|website=www.productschool.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-09-04}}</ref>.
The company is well known for hosting weekly events and workshops with industry professionals at each campus, covering topics such as Product Management, Machine Learning, and how leading tech companies<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.eventbrite.com/o/product-school-7016750825|title=Product School|website=Eventbrite|language=en-us|access-date=2017-09-04}}</ref> manage their product teams.
== History == Product School began in early 2014 in San Francisco founded by Carlos González de Villaumbrosia. It opened its first campus in the [[Financial District, San Francisco|Financial District]] and opened more campuses at the beginning of 2015, one in New York City and the other in Silicon Valley. In 2016, it expanded from three campuses to five, including Los Angeles and Santa Monica. It also added a new course that same year, Coding for Managers. In early 2017 the company opened an Orange County campus and in August of 2017, launched the Data Analytics for Managers course. More recently, the company opened further campuses in Austin, Bellevue, Boulder, Boston, Chicago, Denver, Seattle and outside of the United States, in London, UK and Toronto, Canada. In the summer of 2018, Product School launched its online campus and added two new courses, Blockchain & Cryptocurrencies and Digital Marketing for Managers.
The company's founder, Carlos González de Villaumbrosia has created three companies in the education space and has worked in building digital products in [[Europe]], [[Latin America]] and the [[United States|U.S]]. Prior to founding Product School, he worked as Lead Instructor at [[General Assembly (school)|General Assembly]], teaching product management in San Francisco. Before General Assembly, he was the Co-founder and CEO at [[Floqq]], invested by [https://500.co/startup/floqq/ 500Startups]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://500.co/startup/floqq/|title=Floqq - 500 Startups|website=500.co|language=en-US|access-date=2017-09-04}}</ref>, a marketplace for online courses in Latin America. Prior to founding Floqq, he worked as a Product Marketing Manager at Involver, acquired by [[Oracle Corporation|Oracle]].
In 2010, Villaumbrosia was awarded as one of the top 10 young entrepreneurs in [[Spain]] by [[Banco Santander]] with NetDay<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.blogyuzz.org/tag/carlos-villaumbrosia/|title=Carlos Villaumbrosia archivos - Blog Santander YUZZ - Jóvenes con ideas|website=Blog Santander YUZZ - Jóvenes con ideas|language=es-ES|access-date=2017-09-04}}</ref>, the world's first Open Innovation Platform in schools and universities, devoted to inspire and connect students with thought leaders.
The organization is 100% bootstrap-funded and has not received any private or public investments.
In 2017 it was featured on the [http://breakingintostartups.com/carlos-gonzalez-product-management/ Breaking into Startups] podcast<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://breakingintostartups.com/carlos-gonzalez-product-management/|title=#32: Carlos González de Villaumbrosia - Founder of Product School — Breaking Into Startups|date=2017-03-13|work=Breaking Into Startups|access-date=2017-09-04|language=en-US}}</ref>.
As of August 2018, Product School has 15 campus locations in New York, Silicon Valley, San Francisco, Downtown Los Angeles, Santa Monica, Orange County, Boston, Chicago, Denver, Boulder, Seattle, Bellevue, London (UK) and Toronto (Canada), plus an online campus, with all courses available live. == Course Offerings == Product School teaches 8-week part-time courses in Product Management, Data Analytics, Coding for Managers, Blockchain and Cryptocurrencies and Digital Marketing for Managers, taught by real-world tech instructors<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.productschool.com/instructors/|title=Product Management Instructors and Mentors - Product School|website=www.productschool.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-09-04}}</ref>. The company offers on-site courses at their 15 campuses worldwide and off-site, live, online. The training is performed in small groups through hands-on exercises and case studies to learn how to manage different teams involved in building software products. The topics that are covered include technical interviews, company metrics or advanced queries in [[SQL]], [[A/B testing|A/B tests]], [[business intelligence]] reports or [[Machine learning|Machine Learning]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.productschool.com/product-management-certification/|title=Product Management Certification - Product School|website=www.productschool.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-09-04}}</ref>.
